**Transcript**:
hi everybody this week's flip along is there was an old lady who swallowed a fly by sims tobogg there was an old lady who swallowed a fly i don't know why she swallowed the fly perhaps she'll die but it's only a fly i think i'll cry she gulped it out of the sky oh my there was an old lady who swallowed a spider that wiggled and jiggled and tickled inside her she swallowed the spider to catch the fly i don't know why she swallowed the fly perhaps she'll die gone to the by-and-by sigh there was an old lady who swallowed a bird how absurd she swallowed a bird she swallowed the bird to catch the spider she swallowed the spider to catch the fly i don't know why she swallowed the fly perhaps she'll die she'll leave us high and dry there was an old lady who swallowed a cat imagine that she swallowed a cat she swallowed the cat to catch the bird she swallowed the bird to catch the spider she swallowed the spider to catch the fly i don't know why she swallowed the fly perhaps she'll die i help it's a lie there was an old lady who swallowed a dog she went whole hog to swallow the dog she swallowed the dog to catch the cat she swallowed the cat to catch the bird she swallowed the bird to catch the spider she swallowed the spider to catch the fly i don't know why she swallowed the fly perhaps she'll die there's a tear in my eye there was an old lady who swallowed a cow i don't know how she swallowed the cow she swallowed the cow to catch the dog she swallowed the dog to catch the cat she swallowed the cat to catch the bird she swallowed the bird to catch the spider she saw the spider to catch the fly i don't know why she swallowed the fly perhaps she'll die i'd rather have ham on rye and she had a frog on the sly she did it in one try there was an old lady who swallowed a horse she died of course it was the last course i'm filled with remorse it is such a loss she had no time to floss she missed out on the sauce what's left to say we'll miss her dearly even the artist is crying moral never swallow a horse thanks for reading along with us come back next time for another story

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. my, B. sky, C. cry, D. cat
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the title of the song being recited in the transcript? Options: A. There Was an Old Man, B. There Was an Old Lady Who Swallowed a Fly, C. The Lady's Lament, D. The Old Lady's Tale Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the reason given for the old lady swallowing the fly in the song? Options: A. To catch the spider, B. To eat it, C. Perhaps she'll die, D. To impress her friends Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the old lady's pattern of actions in the song? Options: A. She swallows an animal to catch another animal, which she swallows to catch another animal, and so on., B. She swallows an animal to eat it., C. She swallows an animal to impress her friends., D. She swallows an animal to go to the doctor. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the moral of the song? Options: A. Never swallow a fly, B. Never swallow a horse, C. Never swallow anything, D. It's okay to swallow things, just be careful Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the artist's reaction to the old lady's actions in the song? Options: A. The artist is laughing at the old lady's actions., B. The artist is crying because of the old lady's actions., C. The artist is indifferent to the old lady's actions., D. The artist is angry at the old lady's actions. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What are the consequences of the old lady swallowing a horse, as stated in the song? Options: A. She would get a tummy ache, B. She would die, C. She would get a reward, D. She would go to the doctor Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the theme of the song? Options: A. The dangers of swallowing things, B. The importance of eating healthy, C. The consequences of one's actions, D. The power of imagination Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the tone of the song? Options: A. Happy and upbeat, B. Sad and mournful, C. Serious and cautionary, D. Humorous and playful Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the purpose of the song? Options: A. To entertain the audience, B. To educate the audience about the dangers of swallowing things, C. To warn the audience about the consequences of one's actions, D. To make the audience laugh Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the final line of the song? Options: A. Never swallow a horse, B. We'll miss her dearly, C. It's okay to swallow things, D. The artist is crying Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the last thing the lady swallowed?
Options: A. A frog, B. A cow, C. A horse, D. A dog
Correct Option: C

The artist is crying because of the old lady's actions., C. The artist is indifferent to the old lady's actions., D. The artist is angry at the old lady's actions. Correct Option: B

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does it mean to be a Native American?
Options: A. That you were among the largest group of people living in the United States of America., B. That you are among the most important groups of people living in the United States of America., C. That you were one of the original people who lived in the United States of America., D. That you were one of the founding fathers of the United States of America.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What were the original people who lived in the United States? Options: A. European settlers, B. Native Americans, C. African immigrants, D. Asian traders Correct Option: B
Question 2: How did Native Americans typically live? Options: A. In big cities, B. in tribes and nations with their own religions, traditions, and languages, C. small villages, D. alone Correct Option: B
Question 3: Which Native American tribe was known for its warriors and hunters? Options: A. Cherokee, B. Sioux, C. Navajo, D. Apache Correct Option: B
Question 4: What region would you visit to see the Navajo tribe's original home? Options: A. Northeast, B. Southwest, C. Midwest, D. West Coast Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is another word for farming that Native Americans of the Iroquois tribe were known for? Options: A. Agriculture, B. Hunting, C. Fishing, D. Mining Correct Option: A
Question 6: What type of shelter did the Apache Indians build from branches, leaves, and grass? Options: A. Teepee, B. Wigwam, C. Cabin, D. Tent Correct Option: B
Question 7: How many Native American tribes and nations are there today? Options: A. 100, B. More than 500, C. 1000, D. 2000 Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was unique about the way the Cherokee tribe was known? Options: A. They were known for their agriculture, B. They were known for their warriors and hunters, C. They were known for having another language, D. They were known for their fishing skills Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is a correct statement about Native Americans? Options: A. They were European settlers, B. They were African immigrants, C. They were the original people who lived in the United States, D. They were Asian traders Correct Option: C
Question 10: What can we learn from the diversity of Native American tribes and nations? Options: A. We can learn about their unique skills and traditions, B. We can learn about their history and culture, C. We can learn about their language and customs, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 11: What type of shelter built from branches, leaves, and grass, is commonly associated with Native American tribes? Options: A. Wigwam, B. Teepee, C. Cabin, D. Tent Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is the approximate number of Native American tribes and nations that exist today? Options: A. 100, B. More than 500, C. 1000, D. 2000 Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Not everybody likes the same kind of food, right? That's probably a good thing. 
I mean, all the more pizza for me! But whether we eat milkshakes or mangoes, 
pizzas or pears, tacos or toast, we use the energy that's in 
our food to stay alive. But how did that energy get
 into our food in the first place? The answer is that energy 
flows between living things. It's almost like each form of food 
is a link in a chain...a food chain! You might have heard that humans are on the top of the food chain because we eat pretty much everything, and except for the occasional 
video game monster and maybe the odd bear, 
nothing tries to eat us. But what is a food chain, exactly? A food chain is a model that shows 
how energy flows between living things. You can think of animals and plants in the same food chain as all living in the same neighborhood, 
which scientists call a "habitat." And they all have a job to do, 
interacting with each other, day in and day out. Together, they form a kind of system. A self-contained collection of different things 
that all work together as a whole. And, they also interact with the 
non-living stuff around them, like the water, the air, the ground, and the sun. Put it all together, and what do you get? A special system 
called an "ecosystem!" And food chains show us 
what eats what in an ecosystem. Now, everything that's alive is in a food chain. Including you, my friend! And actually, most living things 
are in more than one food chain, depending on what, or who, 
they're munching on at the moment. I mean, you don't eat the same thing 
for dinner every night, do you? Didn't think so! Now, let's see how a food chain works, by making a diagram of how 
these interactions happen in nature. First, all of the energy that's 
in a food chain starts with the Sun. I can't stress that enough, people! Plants take the energy from the Sun's rays and change it into chemical energy. So, when a nice patch of 
lush, green grass starts to grow, it's capturing some of the energy 
from the Sun to do it. Then when an animal, like a rabbit, 
wanders by and nibbles on that grass, the energy from the plant is 
transferred into the rabbit's body. Now, if hungry hawk decides that the 
rabbit would make a yummy supper, then the energy from the rabbit 
is transferred to the hawk. And in this ecosystem, nothing is large 
or brave enough to take on the hawk. I mean, just look at her! So, we've hit the top of the food chain, and we've just made a nifty model of it. So, a food chain is a model that shows how energy flows between living things in an ecosystem. Energy in a food chain starts with the Sun, which is turned into chemical energy by plants. And this energy moves up the food chain 
as animals eat the plants, and then other animals eat those animals. And speaking of energy, I'm starving! So I'm off to take my place in the food chain. See you next time!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False? Food contains energy?
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

Question 7: What is the result of not having nerves inside your fingernails and toenails? Options: A. You can feel pain when cutting them., B. You can't feel anything when cutting them., C. You can see them., D. You can hear them. Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why haircuts don't hurt? Options: A. Because hair is too thin., B. Because there are no nerves inside your hair., C. Because hair is made of muscles., D. Because hair is very short. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the process of nerves sending messages to the brain and the brain decoding them? Options: A. The sense of touch, B. The sense of hearing, C. The process of nerves sending messages to the brain and the brain decoding them, D. The process of the brain storing information Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the absence of nerves inside your hair, fingernails, and toenails? Options: A. It makes them very sensitive., B. It makes them very thick., C. It means they don't feel anything and therefore don't hurt., D. It makes them very short. Correct Option: C

[Music] Not everybody likes the same kind of food, right? That's probably a good thing. 
I mean, all the more pizza for me! But whether we eat milkshakes or mangoes, 
pizzas or pears, tacos or toast, we use the energy that's in 
our food to stay alive. But how did that energy get
 into our food in the first place? The answer is that energy 
flows between living things. It's almost like each form of food 
is a link in a chain...a food chain! You might have heard that humans are on the top of the food chain because we eat pretty much everything, and except for the occasional 
video game monster and maybe the odd bear, 
nothing tries to eat us. But what is a food chain, exactly? A food chain is a model that shows 
how energy flows between living things. You can think of animals and plants in the same food chain as all living in the same neighborhood, 
which scientists call a "habitat." And they all have a job to do, 
interacting with each other, day in and day out. Together, they form a kind of system. A self-contained collection of different things 
that all work together as a whole. And, they also interact with the 
non-living stuff around them, like the water, the air, the ground, and the sun. Put it all together, and what do you get? A special system 
called an "ecosystem!" And food chains show us 
what eats what in an ecosystem. Now, everything that's alive is in a food chain. Including you, my friend! And actually, most living things 
are in more than one food chain, depending on what, or who, 
they're munching on at the moment. I mean, you don't eat the same thing

lush, green grass starts to grow, it's capturing some of the energy

as animals eat the plants, and then other animals eat those animals. And speaking of energy, I'm starving! So I'm off to take my place in the food chain. See you next time!

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Not everybody likes the same kind of food, right? That's probably a good thing. 
I mean, all the more pizza for me! But whether we eat milkshakes or mangoes, 
pizzas or pears, tacos or toast, we use the energy that's in 
our food to stay alive. But how did that energy get
 into our food in the first place? The answer is that energy 
flows between living things. It's almost like each form of food 
is a link in a chain...a food chain! You might have heard that humans are on the top of the food chain because we eat pretty much everything, and except for the occasional 
video game monster and maybe the odd bear, 
nothing tries to eat us. But what is a food chain, exactly? A food chain is a model that shows 
how energy flows between living things. You can think of animals and plants in the same food chain as all living in the same neighborhood, 
which scientists call a "habitat." And they all have a job to do, 
interacting with each other, day in and day out. Together, they form a kind of system. A self-contained collection of different things 
that all work together as a whole. And, they also interact with the 
non-living stuff around them, like the water, the air, the ground, and the sun. Put it all together, and what do you get? A special system 
called an "ecosystem!" And food chains show us 
what eats what in an ecosystem. Now, everything that's alive is in a food chain. Including you, my friend! And actually, most living things 
are in more than one food chain, depending on what, or who, 
they're munching on at the moment. I mean, you don't eat the same thing 
for dinner every night, do you? Didn't think so! Now, let's see how a food chain works, by making a diagram of how 
these interactions happen in nature. First, all of the energy that's 
in a food chain starts with the Sun. I can't stress that enough, people! Plants take the energy from the Sun's rays and change it into chemical energy. So, when a nice patch of 
lush, green grass starts to grow, it's capturing some of the energy 
from the Sun to do it. Then when an animal, like a rabbit, 
wanders by and nibbles on that grass, the energy from the plant is 
transferred into the rabbit's body. Now, if hungry hawk decides that the 
rabbit would make a yummy supper, then the energy from the rabbit 
is transferred to the hawk. And in this ecosystem, nothing is large 
or brave enough to take on the hawk. I mean, just look at her! So, we've hit the top of the food chain, and we've just made a nifty model of it. So, a food chain is a model that shows how energy flows between living things in an ecosystem. Energy in a food chain starts with the Sun, which is turned into chemical energy by plants. And this energy moves up the food chain 
as animals eat the plants, and then other animals eat those animals. And speaking of energy, I'm starving! So I'm off to take my place in the food chain. See you next time!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A food chain shows...
Options: A. what eats where in an ecosystem, B. what eats when in an ecosystem, C. what eats what in an ecosystem, D. what eats takeout
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[ ♪ Intro ♪ ] It’s that time again! I’m getting a haircut later today. lots of people get them   Sometimes people decide to cut their hair
much shorter, and sometimes they just get a trim, like I am. Even Squeaks had a little trim when he got
a piece of gum stuck his fur, remember, Squeaks? [Squeaks squeaks] But there’s something that all haircuts
have in common: They don’t hurt! When you think about it, it might seem kind
of weird that they don’t. I mean, if you get a cut on almost any other
part of your body, like your finger, it definitely hurts! But when someone cuts your hair, as long as
you hold very still, it doesn’t hurt at all! There’s also another place on our bodies
that it doesn’t hurt to cut, and we do it all the time. Can you guess what it is, Squeaks? [Squeaks guesses] That’s right — our nails! The reason it doesn’t hurt to cut your hair,
toenails, or fingernails is that they don’t have nerves inside them. A nerve is a type of body part you have all
over the inside of your body, kind of like how you have muscles all over. These nerves have a special job to do: they
carry messages between different places in your body. Now, you have lots of body parts. So nerves have lots of jobs. But one of the biggest jobs nerves have is
to help you sense the world around you. Nerves are the reason you can see, hear, smell,
taste … and yes, feel things! Nerves are a big part of the sense of touch. Squeaks, can I touch your nose to show how
this works? [Squeaks squeaks] When you touch something [taps Squeaks on
the nose], it brushes up against your skin. And, like most parts of your body, your skin
has nerves in it. When something touches your skin, it activates,
or kind of ‘turns on’ the nerves. These nerves can feel all kinds of different
things. Some of them feel whether something is warm
or cold. Others can help us tell if something is smooth
or rough. And there are also some that are in charge
of sensing pain. When I tap Squeaks’ nose, some of the nerves
in my finger get switched on, and each one sends a message. Those messages travel through my hands … up
my arm … through a big bundle of nerves that’s in my back … and all the way to
my brain! Then, my brain decodes the messages. It checks if I’ve ever touched anything
like this before, and combines that with any other information it can get, like if I can
see the thing I’m feeling. This all happens really fast, which is how
I can figure out what I’m touching right away — Squeaks’ nose! [Squeaks sneezes] Oh, I’m sorry ! I guess your nose is kinda
ticklish, Squeaks! So, our sense of touch takes more than just
our hands. It also takes our nerves, and our brains,
too! But what about our hair? Well, try this. Pat the top of your head. Just like the skin that’s on your fingers,
the skin that’s under your hair has nerves. So your fingers can feel the top of your head,
and your head can feel your fingers touching it! Just like how Squeaks felt my finger with
his nose. Now find the very end of a piece of hair and
try squeezing it, without pulling on it at all. Your fingers can feel your hair, but your
hair can’t feel your fingers! That’s because there are no nerves inside
your hair. And as long as you’re not pulling on your
hair, or moving it around too much, you’re not going to feel a thing. The same goes for the very ends of your fingernails
and toenails. They don’t have nerves in them either. No nerves means no sense of touch, so they
don’t feel anything. And if there’s no sense of touch, there’s
no pain. So the next time you get a haircut, now you’ll
know why it doesn’t hurt! [Squeaks squeaks] Yikes, you’re right Squeaks — I should
go if I don’t want to be late for my haircut! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! [♪ Outro ♪ ]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When the brain receives a message from the nerves, it decodes the message. What does this mean?
Options: A. The brain receives the message, checks to see if it is a good message or a bad message, decides what steps to take, and then sends the action step back., B. The brain receives the message, checks to see if it feels like the correct message, decides which steps to take next, and then combines it with other messages it is receiving., C. The brain receives the message, checks to see if they have ever sensed something like the message they are receiving before, and combines that with any other information it can get. (If I touch something ,can I also see it), D. The brain receives the message, checks to see if they truly sense it or if it is a false positive, combines that decision with other information and returns a message.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What happens to the blood vessels in your arm or leg when you sit in one position for a while? Options: A. They get bigger, allowing more blood to flow through., B. They get smaller, allowing less blood to flow through., C. They stay the same, unaffected by your position., D. They disappear, stopping blood flow altogether. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why do people sometimes call the feeling of pins and needles "pins and needles"? Options: A. Because it's a type of medical condition., B. Because it sounds like the feeling itself., C. Because it's a sensation that's similar to being poked with pins., D. Because it's a common experience that people have. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main reason why you can feel something when you touch it? Options: A. Because of the shape and size of the object., B. Because of the color and texture of the object., C. Because of the nerves in your body that detect sensations., D. Because of the temperature of the object. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What happens to your nerves when they wake up after being numb? Options: A. They start working properly right away., B. They get confused and start sending mixed signals to your brain., C. They disappear, and new nerves grow in their place., D. They get smaller, and less blood flows through them. Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can you prevent getting pins and needles? Options: A. By sitting or leaning in one position for a long time., B. By moving around regularly and keeping your blood flowing., C. By not touching anything with your hands or feet., D. By not eating or drinking anything. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main function of nerves in your body? Options: A. To carry oxygen and nutrients to your cells., B. To remove waste products from your body., C. To detect sensations and send signals to your brain., D. To control your body temperature. Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why does your leg feel numb when you sit in one position for a while? Options: A. Because it's not getting enough blood flow., B. Because it's getting too much blood flow., C. Because it's not being used., D. Because it's being squeezed by your body. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What happens to the blood flow in your arm or leg when you press on it with your body? Options: A. It increases, allowing more blood to flow through., B. It stays the same, unaffected by your body., C. It decreases, allowing less blood to flow through., D. It disappears, stopping blood flow altogether. Correct Option: C
Question 9: How long does it usually take for the prickling sensation to go away after you move your arm or leg? Options: A. A few minutes., B. A minute or two., C. Several hours., D. A day or two. Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why is it called "pins and needles" when you touch your arm or leg after it's been numb? Options: A. Because it feels like you're being poked with pins., B. Because it's a type of medical condition., C. Because it's a sensation that's similar to being poked with pins., D. Because it's a common experience that people have. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 6: What is the main function of nerves in your body?**

Although the question itself is not an exact match, the correct option (C) "To detect sensations and send signals to your brain" is closely related to the ground truth MCQ's correct option (C) "The brain receives the message, checks to see if they have ever sensed something like the message they are receiving before, and combines that with any other information it can get."

However, an even closer match is:

**Question 3: What is the main reason why you can feel something when you touch it?**

The correct option (C) "Because of the nerves in your body that detect sensations" is closely related to the ground truth MCQ's correct option (C), which mentions the brain decoding messages from nerves.

But the closest match in terms of question intent and content is:

**None of the above questions exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose one, I would say Question 3 is the closest match.**

If I had to provide an index, I would say: **3**

However, I would like to note that the generated MCQs do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content. The ground truth MCQ is more specific and focused on the brain's role in decoding messages from nerves, while the generated MCQs are more general and focused on the function of nerves in the body.

Options: A. A body part that lives at the ends of our fingers and toes., B. A body part that runs all over the inside of your body., C. A body part that lives in our brains., D. A body part that lives in our hearts.

that presses on your arms or legs for a while, like sitting in one position or leaning on
your elbow, it’ll start to go numb and you can’t feel as much with that part of your
body. Then, once you move so you’re not sitting
or leaning that way anymore, your arm or leg starts to get all prickly, almost like you’re
getting lots of tiny pokes all over, even though there’s nothing actually poking you. People sometimes call that feeling pins and
needles. And that sounds a lot like what happened to
me! It’s something that can feel pretty weird,
even though it happens to people all the time. When we say that an arm or leg fell asleep,
we don’t really mean that it was asleep the way you are when you fall asleep at night. It’s just called that because you can’t
feel much with it while it’s numb, almost like it’s sleeping. And that tingling, pins and needles feeling
you get when you shift your position is kind of like your arm or leg is waking up! You get that prickly feeling because your
body is a little bit confused. You might already know that there’s blood
moving everywhere in your body all the time, pumped through little tubes called blood vessels
by your heart. It’s really important that the blood moves
through all the parts of your body, because that’s how they get energy so they can work
properly. But when you sit in one position or lean on
your arm or leg for a while, you’re pressing on those blood vessels and making the tubes
smaller, so not as much blood can get through. And without enough blood, your arm or leg
can start to go numb. The reason you can feel something when you
touch it is because of little things called nerves that are all over your body. Whenever you pick up a toy or touch something
that’s hot or cold or hurts, these nerves are like little messengers that tell your
brain all about what you’re touching. But the nerves only work well if they’re
getting enough blood. I must have sat in a way that was pressing
on his leg for a few minutes, the nerves in my leg weren’t getting enough blood. So my leg stopped being able to feel as much
— it went numb and fell asleep. But then I moved! And once my body wasn’t pressing on his
leg anymore, more blood started moving through it again and his nerves woke up. But nerves get a liiiittle confused when they
wake up. At first, they don’t really know /what/
you’re feeling. They start telling your brain that you’re
feeling tiny little pokes, even though nothing is really touching you! That’s where the pins and needles feeling
comes from. Pretty soon, your nerves get used to having
enough blood again and go right back to normal. So to keep yourself from getting pins and
needles, you can just make sure you don’t sit or lean in one position for too long. And if you do get them, all you have to do
is just wait. You can shake around the arm or leg in the
meantime to help the blood get flowing again, but either way, the prickling will go away
after a minute or two. Whew, Squeaks! It feels like my nerves are finally getting
back to normal! My leg is better now! But now the next time I get pins and needles,
I’ll know all about why it happens. And so will you! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! ♪Outro♪

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What do we call that sharp, poking feeling after you move a leg or arm that has fallen asleep?
Options: A. Pins and Needles, B. Pins and Sledgehammers, C. Needles and Nails, D. Pokers and Pins
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
♪INTRO♪ Hey, Squeaks... (Squeaks squeaks) Oh, I'm ok. My leg just feels kinda weird... It’s tingling, but in a way that feels prickly! [Squeaks Squeaks] Oh yeah, you're right! I think my leg is asleep! Maybe this has happened to you before, too. Sometimes if you’ve been doing something
that presses on your arms or legs for a while, like sitting in one position or leaning on
your elbow, it’ll start to go numb and you can’t feel as much with that part of your
body. Then, once you move so you’re not sitting
or leaning that way anymore, your arm or leg starts to get all prickly, almost like you’re
getting lots of tiny pokes all over, even though there’s nothing actually poking you. People sometimes call that feeling pins and
needles. And that sounds a lot like what happened to
me! It’s something that can feel pretty weird,
even though it happens to people all the time. When we say that an arm or leg fell asleep,
we don’t really mean that it was asleep the way you are when you fall asleep at night. It’s just called that because you can’t
feel much with it while it’s numb, almost like it’s sleeping. And that tingling, pins and needles feeling
you get when you shift your position is kind of like your arm or leg is waking up! You get that prickly feeling because your
body is a little bit confused. You might already know that there’s blood
moving everywhere in your body all the time, pumped through little tubes called blood vessels
by your heart. It’s really important that the blood moves
through all the parts of your body, because that’s how they get energy so they can work
properly. But when you sit in one position or lean on
your arm or leg for a while, you’re pressing on those blood vessels and making the tubes
smaller, so not as much blood can get through. And without enough blood, your arm or leg
can start to go numb. The reason you can feel something when you
touch it is because of little things called nerves that are all over your body. Whenever you pick up a toy or touch something
that’s hot or cold or hurts, these nerves are like little messengers that tell your
brain all about what you’re touching. But the nerves only work well if they’re
getting enough blood. I must have sat in a way that was pressing
on his leg for a few minutes, the nerves in my leg weren’t getting enough blood. So my leg stopped being able to feel as much
— it went numb and fell asleep. But then I moved! And once my body wasn’t pressing on his
leg anymore, more blood started moving through it again and his nerves woke up. But nerves get a liiiittle confused when they
wake up. At first, they don’t really know /what/
you’re feeling. They start telling your brain that you’re
feeling tiny little pokes, even though nothing is really touching you! That’s where the pins and needles feeling
comes from. Pretty soon, your nerves get used to having
enough blood again and go right back to normal. So to keep yourself from getting pins and
needles, you can just make sure you don’t sit or lean in one position for too long. And if you do get them, all you have to do
is just wait. You can shake around the arm or leg in the
meantime to help the blood get flowing again, but either way, the prickling will go away
after a minute or two. Whew, Squeaks! It feels like my nerves are finally getting
back to normal! My leg is better now! But now the next time I get pins and needles,
I’ll know all about why it happens. And so will you! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and we’ll see you next time here at the
Fort! ♪Outro♪

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Falling asleep means that our leg or arm has taken a nap, like we do sometimes., B. Falling asleep means that our leg or arm has stopped working altogether., C. Falling asleep means that our leg or arm has forgotten to work right., D. Falling asleep means that our leg or arm has gone numb and lost feeling.
Correct Option: D

by your heart. It’s really important that the blood moves
through all the parts of your body, because that’s how they get energy so they can work
properly. But when you sit in one position or lean on
your arm or leg for a while, you’re pressing on those blood vessels and making the tubes
smaller, so not as much blood can get through. And without enough blood, your arm or leg
can start to go numb. The reason you can feel something when you
touch it is because of little things called nerves that are all over your body. Whenever you pick up a toy or touch something

brain all about what you’re touching. But the nerves only work well if they’re
getting enough blood. I must have sat in a way that was pressing
on his leg for a few minutes, the nerves in my leg weren’t getting enough blood. So my leg stopped being able to feel as much
— it went numb and fell asleep. But then I moved! And once my body wasn’t pressing on his
leg anymore, more blood started moving through it again and his nerves woke up. But nerves get a liiiittle confused when they

you’re feeling. They start telling your brain that you’re

Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
welcome to my laboratory i want to show you my new machine the pluralator it makes more than one every word has a body a body can have a tail this tale is special it is called a plural the s tells us there is more than one duck that means i can use my plural later see now there are lots of ducks sometimes the tail that is a plural is e s e s makes the sound is boxes so how do you know when to use s or e s use es after one of these hissing sounds glasses dishes bunches now you know how to use tails to show there is more than one plurals what an excellent student you are so clever oh no the plural later is going out of control stop no i must get out of here it is going crazy

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does it mean when a word becomes "plural?"
Options: A. More than one, B. A tail, C. It is all alone
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What sound does the vowel make in an open syllable? Options: A. A short sound, B. The vowel's letter name, C. A diphthong, D. A consonant sound Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following words is an example of a closed syllable? Options: A. Open, B. Hit, C. Oh no, D. Me Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the rule for determining whether a syllable is open or closed? Options: A. The vowel says its letter name if it's at the beginning of the word, B. The vowel makes a short sound if it's at the end of the word, C. The vowel says its letter name if it's open, D. The vowel makes a short sound if it's closed Correct Option: D
Question 4: Identify the correct classification of the syllable in the word "hit". Options: A. Open syllable, B. Closed syllable, C. Diphthong, D. Consonant Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the difference between an open and a closed syllable? Options: A. An open syllable has a vowel at the beginning, while a closed syllable has a vowel at the end, B. An open syllable has a vowel that says its letter name, while a closed syllable has a vowel that makes a short sound, C. An open syllable has a consonant at the beginning, while a closed syllable has a consonant at the end, D. An open syllable has a vowel that makes a long sound, while a closed syllable has a vowel that makes a short sound Correct Option: B
Question 6: Which of the following words can be classified as an open syllable? Options: A. Hit, B. Me, C. Oh, D. Please Correct Option: C
Question 7: What happens to the vowel sound in a closed syllable? Options: A. It says its letter name, B. It makes a short sound, C. It makes a long sound, D. It becomes silent Correct Option: B
Question 8: Identify the correct classification of the syllable in the word "please". Options: A. Open syllable, B. Closed syllable, C. Diphthong, D. Consonant Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can you apply the knowledge of open and closed syllables to improve your reading skills? Options: A. By paying attention to the vowel sounds at the beginning of words, B. By paying attention to the vowel sounds at the end of words, C. By identifying open and closed syllables in words, D. By ignoring the vowel sounds in words Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of understanding the difference between open and closed syllables? Options: A. It helps you to recognize words more easily, B. It helps you to improve your pronunciation, C. It helps you to understand the rules of language, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Correct Option: C

Question 4: What did the bear find in the new forest that he hadn't seen before? Options: A. Great climbing spots, itchy trees, and nice mud, B. A river, C. A new type of berry, D. A beautiful meadow Correct Option: A

Question 8: How did the bear feel when he was being chased by the dog? Options: A. He was happy, B. He was scared, C. He was angry, D. He was surprised Correct Option: D
Question 9: What does the story of the bear eating the sandwich teach us about the importance of being honest? Options: A. It teaches us that honesty is the best policy, B. Question 9: What does the story of the bear eating the sandwich teach us about the importance of being honest? Options: A. It teaches us that honesty is the best policy, B. It teaches us that honesty is not always the best policy, C. It teaches us that honesty is not important, D. It teaches us that honesty is only important in certain situations Correct Option: None

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
[Music] welcome to brightly story time i'm miss linda and today's book is special because it's part of a very cool program called read for the record it's a very funny story about a bear and a sandwich it's called the bear ate your sandwich by julia sarcone roach by now i think you know what happened to your sandwich but you may not know how it happened so let me tell you it all started with the bear the morning air was warm and bright when the bear stepped out of his den he stretched and sniffed the scent of ripe berries drifted toward him and led him to a wonderful discovery [Music] a berry feast the bear curled up in the sunlight and listened to the buzzing of the bees before long he was asleep [Music] by the time the bear opened his eyes the buzzing had become a rumbling he was being quickly swept along like a leaf in a great river the forest disappeared in the distance and high cliffs rose up around him [Music] once the rumbling stopped the bear found himself in a new forest it was like nothing he'd ever seen before this forest had many great climbing spots the trees were still itchy here there was good bark for scratching [Music] and the mud squished nicely under his feet there were many interesting smells in this forest but some of the tastiest ones had already been found leafy green smells led the bear to new fun and that is when he saw it [Music] there it was your beautiful and delicious sandwich all alone he waited to make sure no one saw him not even the sandwich before he made his move [Music] it was such a great sandwich the bear loved it but just as he was almost finished he heard sniff snuffle slobber snort behind him he had been seen the bear was so surprised that he ran out of the park and down the street until he spotted a very tall tree from the top of the tree the bear could see his forest it was time to go home the waves rocked the bear and he began to doze [Music] when he opened his eyes he heard the breeze in familiar branches and the birds and bugs evening song well the bear made it home just fine so that's what happened to your sandwich the bear ate it [Music] i saw it all i tried to save your sandwich i was able to save this little bit of lettuce here the bear dropped it as he ran off but i couldn't save the rest i'm sorry to have to tell you about your sandwich this way but now you know [Music] hmm do you believe the dog story about the sandwich i don't know seems suspicious now it's your turn read the bear ager sandwich yourself or find someone to read it to you and you can always find more books at readbrightly.com thank you so much bye [Music] you

sandwich i was able to save this little bit of lettuce here the bear dropped it as he ran off but i couldn't save the rest i'm sorry to have to tell you about your sandwich this way but now you know [Music] hmm do you believe the dog story about the sandwich i don't know seems suspicious now it's your turn read the bear ager sandwich yourself or find someone to read it to you and you can always find more books at readbrightly.com thank you so much bye [Music] you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A truck brought the bear to the city, but what returned him to his forest?
Options: A. Another truck, B. A car, C. A boat, D. The train
Correct Option: C

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 9
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do we hiccup?
Options: A. Our diaphragm causes our vocal folds to involuntarily spasm causing a hiccup., B. Our lungs involuntarily spasm and cause the diaphragm to clamp down., C. Our diaphragm has an involuntary spasm which causes us to take in a sudden gulp of air and our vocal folds clamp shut., D. Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why people get hiccups?
Options: A. An involuntary spasm of the diaphragm, B. A malfunction of the nervous system, C. A problem with the vocal folds, D. A problem with the lungs
Correct Option: A

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX

   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a diaphragm?
Options: A. A small muscle in between your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing., B. A sac of air pockets that live inside your lung and are most important for breathing., C. A nerve that runs from the base of your skull down your spine and is important for breathing., D. A sheet of muscle underneath your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing.
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: According to the transcript, what is the primary function of the diaphragm?
Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To facilitate digestion, C. To contract suddenly, causing hiccups, D. To expand and contract to facilitate breathing
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we stop hiccups?
Options: A. We have to tell our diaphragm to stop hiccupping., B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax., C. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more to make it change the hiccups., D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the purpose of stimulating the vagus nerve to get rid of hiccups?
Options: A. To increase the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, B. To distract the vagus nerve from constantly zapping the diaphragm, C. To slow down the heartbeat, D. To regulate body temperature
Correct Option: B

people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does swallowing a spoonful of sugar help stop hiccups?
Options: A. Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone., B. Swallowing sugar is too sweet. It refocuses the Vagus Nerve on the incredible sweetness which leaves the diaphragm alone., C. Swallowing sugar stimulates your vocal folds and causes them to relax., D. Swallowing sugar causes your body to inhale a large amount of oxygen which calms your diaphragm.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: According to the transcript, what is swallowing a teaspoon of sugar a recommended hiccup remedy?
Options: A. No, it is not recommended, B. Yes, it is a popular remedy, C. It may be helpful in distracting the vagus nerve, D. It has no effect on hiccups
Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does swallowing a spoonful of sugar help stop hiccups?

It refocuses the Vagus Nerve on the incredible sweetness which leaves the diaphragm alone., C. Swallowing sugar stimulates your vocal folds and causes them to relax., D. Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:

Options: A. No, it is not recommended, B. Yes, it is a popular remedy, C. It may be helpful in distracting the vagus nerve, D. It has no effect on hiccups
Correct Option: C

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 6
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the video, we see that one failure point is if she builds a treehouse, she may be able to stay in but can't have friends over. What is a failure point?
Options: A. A place where a solution to a problem fails., B. A place where a solution to a problem has limits., C. A place where a solution to a problem causes a collapse in the solution., D. A place where a solution to the problem causes another unknown variable.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What are some potential failure points when building the treehouse?
Options: A. The tree might not be able to support the weight of the treehouse, B. The tree might not be able to support the weight of the people inside the treehouse, C. The tree might not be able to support the weight of the blankets used for soundproofing, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.

criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Question: While Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X approached the Civil Rights Movement differently, they did have two things in common. What were they?
Options: A. They were both ministers and they both grew up in Nebraska., B. They were both ministers and they were both assassinated., C. They were both assassinated and they both found religion as adults., D. Both had sick mothers who died and fathers that were ministers.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:

Correct Option: D

Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Malcom X's last name when he was born?
Options: A. Smart, B. X, C. Little, D. Johnson
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What was Malcolm X's birth name?
Options: A. Earl Little, B. Malcolm X, C. Malcolm Little, D. El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz
Correct Option: C

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 3, Matched Generated Question 2
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why was Malcolm's family forced to move from Omaha, Nebraska?
Options: A. They were being attacked by the Ku Klux Klan., B. His father received an important job elsewhere., C. His mother became ill and they moved to be closer to a hospital., D. They didn't have enough money to stay in Omaha.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What group did Malcolm X's father speak out against?
Options: A. The Black Panther Party, B. The Ku Klux Klan, C. The Civil Rights Movement, D. The Nation of Islam
Correct Option: B

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 4, Matched Generated Question 2
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Options: A. They killed his father., B. The made his mother ill., C. They put Malcolm and his siblings in foster care., D. They burned down Malcolm's father's church.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What group did Malcolm X's father speak out against?
Options: A. The Black Panther Party, B. The Ku Klux Klan, C. The Civil Rights Movement, D. The Nation of Islam
Correct Option: B
